citation.article-title: Genetic diversity in Bradyrhizobium japonicum Jordan 1982 and a proposal for Bradyrhizobium elkanii sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Bradyrhizobium elkanii sp. nov.

The same nine group II strains of Hollis et. al. (1981), proposed B. elkanii had an acidic EPS containing rhamnose and 4-O-methyl-glucuronic acid, whereas the 16 B. japonicum strains had an EPS that contained glucose, mannose, galacturonic acid, and galactose (Huber et al. 1984). In addition, the former, but not the latter, had ex planta nitrogenase expression under the conditions employed. In symbiosis with soybean, the major terminal oxidase cytochrome aa3 was present in bacteroids only of the proposed B. elkanii, and unlike B. japonicum these organisms lacked a "hemoglobinlike" CO-reactive hemoprotein P-422 (Keister and Marsh 1990).

The proposed B. elkanii strains had 0.5% 16:1C acid, 11.1% 16:0 acid, 0.8% 17:0 cyclopropane acid, 24.7% 19:0 cyclopropane acid, and 62.3% 18:1 acid. Bradyrhizobium japonicum strains were susceptible to rifampicin (500 μg/mL), tetracycline (100 μg/mL), streptomycin (100 μg/mL), chloramphenicol (500 μg/mL), erythromycin (250 μg/mL), carbenicillin (500 μg/mL), and nalidixic acid (50 μg/mL), whereas the proposed B. elkanii strains were resistant to these antibiotics.
